subSense.re:
to spurt out to
come out in a strong jet ć Oil spurted
out of the burst pipe

subSense.def:
to run fast sud-
denly
subSense.example:
He spurted past two runners
and came in first

subSense.def:
a strong flow
of liquid
subSense.example:
They tried to block the spurts
of water coming out of the pipe

subSense.def:
a person who is paid to
try to find out secret information about
the enemy or a rival group
subSense.example:
He was ex-
ecuted as a Russian spy

subSense.def: to work as a spy
subSense.re:
to
spy on someone to watch someone in
secret, to find out what they are plan-
ning to do ć We discovered that our
neighbours had been spying on us

subSense.def:
a squalid
room or building is dirty and unpleasant
subSense.example:
The prisoners are kept in squalid con-
ditions

subSense.def:
a shape with
four equal sides and four right-angled
corners
subSense.example:
The board on which you play
chess is made up of black and white
squares

Graph paper is covered with
small squares

subSense.def:
an open space in a
town, with big buildings all round
subSense.example:
The
hotel is in the main square of the town,
opposite the town hall

Red Square is
in the middle of Moscow

subSense.def:
a number
that is the result of multiplying another
number by itself
subSense.example: 9 is the square of 3

subSense.def:
shaped like a square, with
four equal sides and four right-angled
corners
subSense.example:
You can't fit six people round
a small square table

An A4 piece of
paper isn't square

subSense.def:
multiplied by it-
self

to crush or to
squeeze something
subSense.example:
Hundreds of pas-
sengers were squashed into the train
He sat on my hat and squashed it flat

subSense.def:
a fast game for two players played
in an enclosed court, with a small,
squashy rubber ball and light, long-han-
dled rackets
subSense.example:
He plays squash to un-
wind after a day at the office

Let's
play a game of squash

body.subSense:
to move your body
close to the ground so that you are sit-
ting on your heels ć She squatted on the
floor, trying to get the stains out of the
carpet. (NOTE: squats -squatting -
squatted)

subSense.def:
a quiet high
sound like the sound that a mouse
makes
subSense.example:
You can tell when someone
comes into the garden by the squeak of
the gate

subSense.def: to make a squeak
subSense.example:
That door squeaks -the hinges need oil-
ing

subSense.def: a loud high noise
subSense.example:
The children let out squeals of delight
when they saw the presents under the
Christmas tree

The car turned the
corner with a squeal of tyres

subSense.def:
to
make a loud high-pitched noise
subSense.example:
She
squealed when she heard she had won
first prize

As the car turned the cor-
ner its tyres squealed

subSense.def:
the act of press-
ing or crushing
subSense.example:
I gave her hand a
squeeze

subSense.def:
to press on some-
thing or to press or crush something like
a fruit or a tube to get something out of
it
subSense.example: She squeezed my arm gently

He
squeezed an orange to get the juice

She squeezed some toothpaste out onto
her brush

subSense.def:
to force something, or to
force your own body, into a small space
subSense.example:
You can't squeeze six people into that
little car

More people tried to squeeze
on the train even though it was full al-
ready

The cat managed to squeeze
through the window

subSense.def:
a small red or
grey wild animal with a large tail which
lives in trees and eats nuts
subSense.example:
The squir-
rel sat up on a branch nibbling a nut
Squirrels hoard nuts for the winter

subSense.def:
to send out a thin
powerful flow of liquid
subSense.example:
Don't squirt
so much washing-up liquid into the
bowl

She squeezed the tube hard and
masses of toothpaste squirted out

subSense.def: street
saint

body.subSense:
to push a sharp knife
with force into someone or something ć
He was stabbed in the chest. (NOTE:
stabs -stabbing -stabbed)

subSense.def:
a deep wound made by the point of a
knife
subSense.example: He died of stab wounds

subSense.def:
which does
not change
subSense.example:
The hospital said his con-
dition was stable

subSense.def:
a building for
keeping a horse
subSense.example:
My horse is not in his
stable, who's riding him

subSense.def:
a pile or heap of
things one on top of the other
subSense.example:
a stack
of books and papers

subSense.def:
to pile
things on top of each other
subSense.example:
The skis
are stacked outside the chalet

She
stacked up the dirty plates

The ware-
house is stacked with boxes

body.subSense:
a large build-
ing where crowds of people watch sport,
with seats arranged around a sports field
(NOTE: The plural is stadiums or sta-
dia.)

all the people who
work in a company, school, college, or
other organisation ć She's on the school
staff. ć Only staff can use this lift. ć A
quarter of our staff are ill. ć That firm
pays its staff very badly. ć He joined the
staff last Monday. ć Three members of
staff are away sick. (NOTE: staff refers
to a group of people and so is often fol-
lowed by a verb in the plural.)

subSense.def:
a raised floor, es-
pecially where the actors perform in a
theatre
subSense.example:
The pop group came onto the
stage and started to sing

subSense.def:
one of sev-
eral points of development
subSense.example:
the differ-
ent stages of a production process

The
first stage in the process is to grind the
rock to powder

subSense.def:
a section of a long
journey
subSense.example:
Stage one of the tour takes us
from Paris to Bordeaux

subSense.def:
to put on
or arrange a play, a show, a musical or
other performance or event
subSense.example:
The exhi-
bition is being staged in the college li-
brary

subSense.def:
to walk in way
that is not steady or controlled, almost
falling down
subSense.example:
She managed to stagger
across the road and into the police sta-
tion

Three men staggered out of the
pub

subSense.def: to surprise someone very much
subSense.example:
I was staggered at the amount they
charge for service

subSense.def:
to arrange some-
thing such as holidays or working hours,
so that they do not all begin and end at
the same time
subSense.example:
We have to stagger the
lunch hour so that there is always some-
one on the switchboard

subSense.def:
the
movement of someone who is stagger-
ing
subSense.example:
He walked with a noticeable stag-
ger

subSense.def:
a mark which is diffi-
cult to remove, e.g. ink or blood
subSense.example:
It is
difficult to remove coffee stains from the
tablecloth

There was a round stain on
the table where he had put his wine
glass

subSense.def:
to make a mark of a differ-
ent colour on something
subSense.example:
If you eat
those berries they will stain your teeth
His shirt was stained with blood

subSense.def:
one step in a series of
steps, going up or down inside a build-
ing
subSense.example: He was sitting on the bottom stair

subSense.def:
a set of stairs
which go from one floor in a building to
another

a strong pointed piece
of wood or metal, pushed into the
ground to mark something, or to hold
something up
subSense.example:
They hammered stakes
into the ground to put up a wire fence
The apple trees are attached to stakes

subSense.def:
food which is stale
is old and no longer fresh

the stem of a plant
which holds a leaf, a flower or a fruit
subSense.example:
Roses with very long stalks are more ex-
pensive

subSense.def:
to stay near someone
and watch him or her all the time, espe-
cially in a way that is frightening or up-
setting
subSense.example:
She told the police that a man
was stalking her

The hunters stalked
the deer for several miles

subSense.def:
a place in a market
where one person sells his or her goods
subSense.example:
He has a flower stall at Waterloo Sta-
tion

We wandered round the market
looking at the stalls

subSense.def:
to stop unintentionally, often
when trying to drive off without acceler-
ating
subSense.example:
If he takes his foot off the accel-
erator, the engine stalls

The car
stalled at the traffic lights and he
couldn't restart it

subSense.def:
to repeat
sounds when speaking, e.g. because of
feeling nervous
subSense.example:
He stammers badly
when making speeches

She rushed
into the police station and stammered
out 'he's -

's -he's after me, he's got
-got -a knife'

subSense.def:
a speech prob-
lem that involves hesitating and repeat-
ing sounds when speaking
subSense.example:
Because of
his stammer he was shy and reserved at
school

subSense.def:
a little piece of
paper with a price printed on it which
you stick on a letter to show that you
have paid for it to be sent by post
subSense.example:
a
first-class stamp

She forgot to put a
stamp on the letter before she posted it

He wants to show me his stamp col-
lection

subSense.def: a mark made on something
subSense.example:
The invoice has the stamp 'received with
thanks' on it

The customs officer
looked at the stamps in his passport

subSense.def: to mark something with a stamp
subSense.example:
They stamped my passport when I en-
tered the country

subSense.def:
to walk, or to put
your feet down, with loud or forceful
steps
subSense.example:
They stamped on the ants to kill
them

He was so angry that he
stamped out of the room

subSense.def:
to be upright on
your feet and not sitting or lying down
subSense.example:
She stood on a chair to reach the top
shelf

They were so tired they could
hardly keep standing

If there are no
seats left, we'll have to stand

Don't
just stand there doing nothing -come
and help us

subSense.def: to be upright
subSense.example:
Only a
few houses were still standing after the
earthquake

The jar was standing in
the middle of the table

body.subSense:
3. to accept
something bad that continues ć The of-
fice is filthy -I don't know how you can
stand working here. ć She can't stand
all this noise. ć He stopped going to
French lessons because he couldn't
stand the teacher. (NOTE: stands -
standing -stood /stυd/)

subSense.def: something which holds something up
subSense.example: The pot of flowers fell off its stand

subSense.def:
the level
of quality something has
subSense.example:
The stand-
ard of service in this restaurant is very
high

This piece of work is not up to
your usual standard

subSense.def:
an excellent
quality which something or someone is
expected to achieve
subSense.example:
This product does
not meet our standards

She has set a
standard which it will be difficult to
match

subSense.def: a large official flag
subSense.example:
The roy-
al standard flies over Buckingham Pal-
ace

subSense.def: usual, not special
subSense.example: She joined on a standard contract

You will need to follow the standard pro-
cedure to join the association

subSense.def:
on a
tall pole

a piece of wire
which is pushed through papers and
bent over to hold them together
subSense.example:
He
used some scissors to take the staples
out of the papers

subSense.def:
to fasten pa-
pers together with a staple or with sta-
ples
subSense.example:
Don't staple the cheque to the or-
der form

subSense.def:
a bright object which
can be seen in the sky at night like a very
distant bright light
subSense.example:
On a clear night
you can see thousands of stars

The
pole star shows the direction of the
North Pole

subSense.def:
a shape that has several
points like a star
subSense.example:
Draw a big star and
colour it red

subSense.def:
a famous person who is
very well known to the public
subSense.example:
football
stars
Who is your favourite film star?

body.subSense:
to appear as a main character in
a film or play ć She starred in 'Gone
with the Wind'. ć He has a starring role
in the new play. (NOTE: stars -starring
-starred)
